The Chinese government spends more on civilian surveillance than military. As westernization of China proliferates along with an educated society, this cost will skyrocket. Either China's back will break under the weight of its authoritarian policies, or there will be a radical transformation towards democracy.

It is also worthy to mention that these costs coupled with a need for a strong military, rising wages, and environmental protection have not been factored into the equation. It is hard to believe that China will be able to maintain solid growth with these issues at the forefront.

I used to enjoy college basketball.  I wonder when it will come back.  Hypothesis: The best teams in college basketball are less likley to have team graduation rates that match the schools they come from.  How well does Kentucky's basketball team graduation rate compare with the school's overall graduation rate?  When was the last time a team that won the championship (or made the final four) had a higher or similar percentage of graduates compared to the school as a whole?  How has that metric tracked over time?  Just curious.

These investors are ridiculous. They are walking into a nightmare...Just one good personal injury case against them and they are out a couple of millions. I bet their fancy technological calculation does not have a line for how much each injury due to any slight negligence in the remodeling will cost them:
1) Simple broken leg: about $50,000
2) Herniated disc: about $100,000
3) Two leg paralysis: $1,000,000 - plus
They may have purchased insurance, but if there are multiple injuries due to below par remodeling across various homes, the group of plaintiffs can unite into a class action (easy in California)-- and, then the cost is exorbitant and their insurance will go through the roof -- Or the insurance company will just stop insuring them...they have a history of that in California. Insurance companies rarely insure for earthquakes anymore -- Oh, did I mention how they will lose all their investment with just one big earthquake? They are fools...and we all know what they say about fools and their money...

Is there anything that's more of a crapshoot nowadays than MLB relievers? Seems for every three a team signs, at least one goes down with an injury. And every year there are a few relievers that were previously mediocre that have it all come together.

Tyler asked the question, "What's the next big thing?" Why doesn't a team take a flier with Mike Marshall's pitching approach with some borderline prospects? What have they got to lose? (other than pride, of course. lol)

Ditto to all the complaints listed by other readers.  Especially on easy access (lack thereof). Function first, folks! What good is a car people can't get into?  Go check old movies from the 1940s that show vehicles with the back doors hinged to swing backward, not forward.  This makes is easy to climb in and out of the back seat, compared to the gyrations required by current vehicles. The new design seems like reverse progress.  Back to the drawing board, please, before it's too late.  Millions of people will be affected for decades to come.

If the US wants to keep China from becoming no. 1, then why do we keep telling them that to ignore "human rights, equality, transparency, and accountability" will plunge them into an abyss?
It would seem that giving our goals to hold them back that it would be better not to tell them what to do about these "universal principles" in order to reach our goal of keeping them from becoming #1.
Our are we being schizoid?
Since they seem to perceive that we want them to fail. why would they believe in the honesty of our recommendations as to how China can avoid failure?

It is true that the U.S. government is hell bent on preventing China from becoming number one. It it true that U.S. NGOs are instruments of U.S. intelligence agencies and are hell bent on f****** up all non-western countries. It is true that the West uses human rights to try to keep poor countries inpoverished. It is not true that the west is in decline - in fact the West is plunging into oblivion now because of the greedy, stupid, moronic behavior of the trash who control things.

Nonetheless, CPC is very mistaken if they believe that human rights, equality, transparency, and accountability are mere slogans to be ignored. The lack of adherence to those universal principles is why the West is now plunging into the abyss. Instead of learning from the West's mistakes, CPC seems hell bent on doing the same moronic things that the West has done. The results won't be any better for CPC.

Instead, all their greedy, scheming, conniving will do is bring about a Japanese Century. You heard it here first.

Mr. Wang isn't wrong, he is reporting what he hears and sees. I wonder how this article will be seen at the top in China. Here, too. There are myriad, monumental issues within both countries, but the U.S. has less of a climb to get back - if we allow it.

It seems we pay our government to be paranoid, and we are really getting our money's worth. Once the momentum builds on the way down this spiral, it will very difficult to stop until something really nasty happens.

Since we can't depend on our paranoid brothers to stay on this side of sanity, we need to step up the communications with China. With people just like us. People who raise families and start businesses. In fact, as pollyanish as it sounds, business people could be the key to long-term stability, cross-pollinating our economies to such a high degree, we can't possibly engage in conflict. This opportunity couldn't have happened in time past. But, we can do it now.

NY Times: It is inaccurate to say Nebraska is a "red state."  Is it mostly red? Yes.  But, as you should note, the state allots its Electoral College votes proportionally.  One of those votes -- from the district centered on Omaha -- went to Obama, the first to a Democrat since 1964.  Based on that, Nebraska is a mixed state, if anything.  And harking back to when Kerrey was in the Senate, Nebraska also had a Democratic governor: now-Senator Ben Nelson.

Ratzo, you should add to your list of 'shirkers' the name of another Nebraskan and Lincolnite Dick Cheney.
The State GOP tried to demean Kerrey when he first ran for the Senate by saying that he threw away his Congressional Medal of Honor. I have the photos to disprove it.

No, you guys can keep him out there.

I'm a teacher at The New School where he was president ... and where the faculty gave him a vote of no confidence. He had some concepts that weren't bad, but -- strangely enough for a politician -- was not so good on personal (or maybe academic) politics.

But here's my favorite interaction:

After the vote of no confidence, Kerrey was shaken & actually tried to make needed changes. Not long afterweards I happened to run into him in a midtown lobby. I introduced myself & told him I thought things were on a better track now. He thanked me & asked what I taught. I said screenwriting & he then said what nearly _everyone_ does at that point, "Boy, do I have a story for you that should be a movie."

But this time it's a guy who was a Seal in Viet Nam, won a Congressional Medal of Honor, was a state Governor, US senator, Commissioner of the 9/11 panel on the WTC attacks, president of a storied NYC university ... and my God, even dated Debra Winger! So maybe -- finally -- I really am going to hear a story worthy of being a movie.

So what does he share with me?

A friend was engaged to be married but had a final fling with a prostitute who ended up getting pregnant. She comes & tells the guy she's having his baby & he then does the "honorable" thing: calls off the marriage to be with the woman having his child.

Really? Of all the stories and experiences you've had, THAT'S the one that needs to be immortalized?

He's all yours Nebraska!!

Part 1...

Allen B., intending sarcasm (rather incompetently, BTW), you ended telling a truth (what perhaps would have been called a Freudian slip in years gone by). The entire country seems to be getting dumber and less well informed each year. Winston Churchill once commented, "The best argument against democracy is a five-minute chat with an average voter."

Political life is not at all complex. Eisenhower's Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, put it plainly when he said "...somehow we find it hard to sell our values, namely that the rich should plunder the poor."

Lest you write that off to Republican attitudes of the '50s, I offer Weekly Standard's editor, Bill Kristol's recent comment, ""[Among conservatives] there's been too much pseudo-populism, almost too much concern and attention for, quote, 'the people'.... After all, we conservatives are on the side of the lords and barons.... We...are pulling up the drawbridge against the peasants."

For the last 80 years or so, It was always part of the country's social contract that any person working a full-time job deserves and should be paid a secure living wage - how quaint that now is, with many full-time workers earning so little that they must get food stamps and other aid for the poor just to survive.
You could at least spell his name correctly while disparaging him.

Today's average worker makes at least three widgets a day for his boss to sell, yet only gets paid in real spendable net income, what his father was paid for one-third of his productivity. Guess where ALL of the profit for the other two widgets you built today goes? Certainly not into your salary to recompense you for your output. Meanwhile, the Wall Street firms I have consulted to for decades (and now refuse to work with) are laughing hysterically and privately mocking us suckers and bumpkins, telling themselves that now that they have sheered us sheep of all our wool, it is time to skin us to pick up the last little inconsequential (to them) pocket change.

Did you know that the top hedge fund managers, like John Paulson, who conspired with Goldman Sachs in 2007 to create and sell mortgage-backed derivatives consisting of the most likely to fail mortgages they could find, and turned around and bought Credit Default Swaps (a form of insurance that pays off the CDS holder if the housing bubble collapses, or even if just these mortgage-backed derivatives failed - as they were designed to do. People like Paulson are essentially taking out insurance on other peoples' properties, betting against our own national economy, and making well over $2 million dollars AN HOUR. And they pay at MOST, 14% in federal wage taxes.

CDSs are like your hated neighbor being able to take out a monster insurance policy on your own house, while he stockpiles jerrycans full of gas.
